metadata.title: Synthesis of <ce:small-caps>l</ce:small-caps>-methionine stabilized nickel nanowires and their application for catalytic oxidative transfer hydrogenation of isopropanol

Fig. 1 The UV–vis spectra recorded for (a) pH study with variation of pH 3–11 from right to left with shift in λ max from 400nm to 360nm and increase in absorbance (b) time study of l-meth-Ni NWs samples showing stable absorption band at 361nm after 3h, 12h, 24h, 36h, 48h, one week, 2 weeks and 1 month. Fig. 2 FTIR spectra of (a) standard l-methionine and (b) Ni NWs functionalized with l-methionine. Fig. 3 The high resolution SEM images obtained from formation of Ni NWs with, (a) 1:2, (b) 1:4 and (c) 1:6 Ni/l-methionine molar ratios. Fig. 4 XRD patterns of respective Ni NWs shown in Fig. 3. Fig. 5 UV–vis spectra for catalytic transfer hydrogenation of IPA to acetone (a) varying concentration of NaBH4 in the range of 0.001–0.01M at fixed concentration (0.12M) of IPA in absence of Ni NWs (b) varying concentration of IPA in the range 0.02–0.12M at fixed amount of Ni NWs (0.1mg) and 0.005M NaBH4; inset shows the corresponding linear trend (c) at fixed concentration of 0.12M IPA with varying amounts 0.1–0.5mg Ni NWs and 0.005M NaBH4; inset gives the corresponding exponential trend (d) calibration curve showing increase in absorbance with varying concentration of acetone in the range of 0.02–0.13M; inset shows the corresponding linear plot. Scheme 1 Mechanism of formation of Ni NWs using hydrazine as reducing agent. Scheme 2 Mechanism of transfer hydrogenation of IPA to form acetone in the presence of NiNWs and NaBH4. Table 1 Performance of re-used Ni NWs (immobilized on cover slips) showing repeated catalytic oxidation of IPA to acetone. Cycle no. Absorbance Acetone formation (%) 1 1.17 99.2 2 1.15 97.5 3 1.12 94.9 4 1.08 91.5 5 1.02 86.4 Synthesis of l-methionine stabilized nickel nanowires and their application for catalytic oxidative transfer hydrogenation of isopropanol Nazar Hussain Kalwar a Sirajuddin a ⁎ Syed Tufail H. Sherazi a Muhammad Ishaq Abro b Zulfiqar Ali Tagar a Syeda Sara Hassan a Yasmin Junejo a Manzoor Iqbal Khattak c a National Center of Excellence in Analytical Chemistry, University of Sindh, Jamshoro, 76080, Pakistan b Department of Metallurgy and Materials Engineering, Mehran University of Engineering & Technology, Jamshoro 76080, Pakistan c Department of Chemistry, Balochistan University, Quetta, Pakistan ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +92 9213429; fax: +92 9213431. Graphical abstract Highlights ► Simple method was investigated for the fabrication of nickel nanowires (Ni NWs). ► l-methionine acted as capping as well as stabilizing agent for Ni NWs. ► Formed Ni NWs proved as catalysts for 100% conversion of isopropanol to acetone. Nickel nanowires (Ni NWs) were synthesized by the reducing action of hydrazine and stabilized by capping with l-methionine in aqueous solution. Characterization of the Ni NWs was carried out by UV–vis spectrometry, Fourier transform infra-red (FTIR) spectroscopy, Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) and X-ray diffractometry (XRD). Parameters like pH, concentration of reducing agent and molar ratio of Ni/l-methionine were found crucial for regulating the size of synthesized Ni NWs. The fabricated Ni NWs were employed as catalyst for catalytic oxidative dehydrogenation (transfer hydrogenation) of isopropanol (IPA) to acetone using aqueous medium in the presence of sodium borohydride (NaBH4) as hydrogen source. The effect of parameters studied during transfer hydrogenation of IPA included the concentration of IPA, concentration of NaBH4, time of reaction and amount of Ni NWs. The study revealed that IPA could be transformed into acetone with 100% yield in only 1min time of reaction. The catalyst was easy to recover and capable to be reused several times. The study shows that the catalytic transformation of IPA into acetone by synthesized Ni NWS in aqueous medium is environmental friendly in terms of recovery of catalyst, very fast and hence extremely economical. Keywords Nickel nanowires Hydrazine monohydrate l-Methionine, Heterogeneous catalysis Isopropanol Acetone 1 Introduction The current interest in fabrication of nanostructured materials is due to their fascinating applications in several important fields such as chemical and electrochemical catalysis, optical switches, microelectronic devices, sensors and so on [1–3]. Being one of the mostly studied areas in chemistry, catalysis plays the major role in several synthetic as well as environmental applications and its important correlation with nanomaterials is the need of the recent research. The facts related to such correlation have been uncovered in a recent review on the role of nanomaterials in catalysis [4]. Main discussion of the reviewers was focused upon the importance and dependence of shape, size, composition and structure of nanosized materials upon various types of catalytic reactions such as hydrogenation, dehydrogenation, alkylation and oxidation. Among nanostructured materials, one-dimensional nanostructures such as nanowires, nanorods, nanotubes, nanofibers, nanochains are more important due to certain special applications including catalysis [5–7]. Reportedly, Ni NWs are considered as ideal materials for basic research and applications in electronic, optical, magnetic and magnetic nanodevices, batteries, drug delivery and catalysis [8–10]. Dehydrogenation or oxidative dehydrogenation of IPA is taken as a model test for checking the catalytic potential of a catalyst [11]. The catalytic dehydrogenation of IPA to acetone in aqueous medium is important for three reasons; (i) to improve the water quality in terms of IPA contamination (ii) testing the selectivity of the catalyst for acetone conversion and (iii) recovery of acetone as useful industrial product by fractional distillation or rotary evaporation. Such processes thus result not only in improving the water quality containing IPA for drinking/washing purpose in terms of hygiene [12] but are equally of high economical nature due to industrial importance [13]. The complicated and time consuming procedures for preparation of catalyst along with its application accompanied by delayed output in the form of products in the mentioned reports [11–13] render these processes highly expensive and hence difficult to implement at industrial scale. The use of nanostructures as catalytic agents is the only answer to such queries, which are based on simpler and shortcut fabrication methods with higher catalytic output in lesser time as compared to macro or micro sized catalysts. An example is the use of poly (vinyl alcohol) PVA protected and unprotected colloidal platinum nanoparticles (Pt NPs) of which unprotected Pt NPs exhibited higher activity [14]. However due to expensive nature of Pt salt and non-recoverable aspect of Pt NPs, still the process seems a bit expensive. Until now there is no report about the use of Ni NWs for conversion of IPA into acetone via catalytic oxidative dehydrogenation. Here we report a very simple one-pot method for the synthesis of l-methionine protected Ni NWs and their application as heterogeneous, recoverable and reusable catalyst for exceptionally faster and complete oxidative transfer hydrogenation of IPA to acetone in the presence of NaBH4 in only 1min time. The whole research work is based on excellent economy of the process in terms of using cheaper chemicals, facile and simpler synthesis of catalyst, lesser time for product formation (quicker procedure) and easy recovery and reuse of catalyst. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Nickel (II) chloride (NiCl2·6H2O, 97%), hydrazine hydrate (N2H4. H2O, 80%), sodium hydroxide pellets (NaOH, 99%), sodium borohydride (NaBH4, 98%), isopropyl alcohol (CH3CH2CHOH, 99%), acetone (CH3COCH3, 97%) and hydrochloric acid (HCl, 37%) were purchased from E. Merck, and l-methionine (C5H11NO2S) from Fluka Chemicals. All the chemicals were analytical grade reagents and used as received without further purification. The solutions of metal salt, reducing agent, and capping agent were all freshly prepared in deionized water for each experiment during optimization and characterizations studies. 2.2 Preparation of standard stock solutions Stock solutions of 0.01M nickel (II) chloride, 0.1M hydrazine monohydrate and 0.01M l-methionine were prepared by dissolving appropriate amounts of the respective compounds in deionized water. Solutions of 1M NaOH and 3M HCl were also prepared in deionized water to adjust the pH from 3 to 11. The stock solutions of 0.2M sodium borohydride, 1M IPA and 1.6M acetone were prepared by dissolving desired quantity of each in deionized water. 2.3 Procedure for synthesis of Ni NWs In a typical procedure 0.2ml of 0.01M Ni solution was taken into a 10ml volumetric flask. To this was added 1.8ml of 0.1M hydrazine hydrate solution followed by 1.2ml of 0.01M l-methionine and diluted to the mark with deionized water. During the course of reduction, color of the sample solution was changed rapidly from grass green to sky blue when different concentrations of Ni, hydrazine and l-methionine were used. As prepared sample solution was transferred to 1cm quartz cell and the UV–vis spectra taken against a blank in order to monitor the fabrication of Ni NWs. The reaction temperature of solution was 25±1°C while the final reaction time was 30min. The proposed mechanism for reduction of Ni2+ to Ni0 with hydrazine is given in Scheme 1 below. 2.4 Preparation of Ni NWs as heterogeneous catalyst Ni NWs were immobilized by adsorption on broken pieces of glass cover slips and dried under N2 for 10min. These pieces were weighed before and after immobilization of Ni NWs to know the amount of Ni NWs by difference. Due to several preparations only the pieces with whole weight of Ni NWs in the range of 0.1–0.5mg were used in catalysis experiments. 2.5 Procedure for catalytic performance of Ni NWs and acetone formation The pieces of glass containing immobilized Ni NWs were put inside the solution containing appropriate amount of IPA and NaBH4 in a 4ml capacity quartz cell and the UV–vis spectra recorded under normal laboratory conditions following three different experimental protocols, including (i) varying concentration of NaBH4 at fixed concentration of IPA in absence of Ni NWs (ii) varying concentration of IPA at fixed amount of Ni NWs in the presence of NaBH4 and (iii) at fixed concentration of IPA and NaBH4 with varying amounts of Ni NWs. The optimized concentration of NaBH4 (0.005M) and Ni NWs (0.5mg) were found to be best for complete catalytic oxidative dehydrogenation of IPA (see Fig. 5(c and d)). 2.6 Calibration of acetone The UV–vis spectra were recorded to get a calibration curve for varying concentration of acetone. The amount of acetone formed in each catalytic experiment was known from linear regression equation of the calibration plot. 2.7 Recovery and reuse of Ni NWs as catalyst After completion of catalytic reaction, the broken pieces containing immobilized Ni NWs were taken out of the cell, washed 3 times by deionized water and dried under N2 as before. These glass pieces having Ni NWs were reused in a fresh IPA solution for checking its second performance as catalyst in a solution prepared by procedure given in 2.5. Similar process was repeated 5 times to see any change in the performance of catalytic activity of reused Ni NWs. 2.8 Instrumentation All UV–vis spectroscopy studies were conducted by double beam Spectrophotometer model Lambda 35 of PerkinElmer equipped with a cell of 1.0cm2 area. The FTIR spectra of Ni NWs and l-methionine were performed by model Nicolet 5700 of Thermo after incorporating the dried sample in solid state KBr disc. The SEM imaging of Ni NWs was carried out by model JSM 6380 Analytical Scanning Electron Microscope (ASEM) of Jeol, Japan. XRD patterns of Ni NWs were investigated by Model D-8 of Bruker using powder method with methionine capped Ni NWs powder as target material between 2θ wavelength range of 37–800. 2.9 Sample preparation for SEM imaging, XRD and FTIR studies 10μl volume of colloidal dispersions of l-methionine encapsulated Ni NWs was placed on a glass cover slip, dried at 100°C on a hot plate, cooled and processed for SEM imaging after carbon coating for 5min. For XRD and FTIR studies, such sample of Ni NWs was prepared in bulk by pouring Ni NWs containing solution in big petri dish, dried on a hot water bath already set at 100°C and cooled at room temperature. The product was washed several times with deionized water and methanol to remove any unreacted or uncoordinated amino acid molecules, dried for 15min in an oven already set at 100°C and re-cooled to room temperature. The product was then collected and processed for XRD and FTIR spectroscopy. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The UV–vis Spectrometry The UV–vis spectra showing the effect of volume of 0.01M Ni (II) ions, 0.1M hydrazine hydrate and 0.01M l-methionine in the range of 0.2–0.4ml, 0.6–1.8ml (the capping agent) and 0.4–1.2ml, respectively on the absorbance and shift in λ max of Ni NWs are given in Fig. S1. The right peak clearly distinguishes the Ni(II) ions from synthesized Ni NWs in Fig. S1(a). The figure further says that increase in Ni(II) ions results in the formation of more Ni NWs as evident by increase in absorbance. UV–vis absorption band around 300–350nm has resulted from the Ni NPs solution, which is attributed to the surface plasmon resonance (SPR) band of Ni0 particles [15]. An absorption peak at a little longer wavelength observed in our experiments in the range 360–400nm is due to formation of Ni NWs. Fig. S1(b) says that increase in the concentration of reducing agent results in a blue shift in the range of 380–369nm. The blue shift is indicative of the formation of smaller nanostructures according to increase in reducing agent [16]. Fig. S1(c) tells that a further blue shift in wavelength from 369nm to 361nm is accompanied with increase in concentrations of l-methionine. This proves that higher concentration of capping agent isolates the nanostructures more efficiently and is thus decisive for controlling the size of Ni NWs. The control in size of Ni NWs with varying concentration of capping agent has also been accomplished by other workers [8]. The UV–vis spectra reveal that 0.2ml of 0.01M Ni (II) solution, 1.8ml of 0.1M hydrazine hydrate and 1.2ml of 0.01M l-methionine were optimum volumes for synthesis of Ni NWs as mentioned in experimental section. The UV–vis spectra showing the effect of pH in the range of 3–11 and the effect of time on fabrication of Ni NWs and stability are highlighted in Fig. 1(a and b), respectively. The color of solution changed from grass green to sky blue with a slight change in ting of the color from pH 5 to 9 while negligible color was observed in strongly acidic or strongly basic solutions. The UV–vis spectra recorded for neutral to basic pH 7–11 samples showed absorbance in the range of 360–370nm while entirely different behavior was true for acidic samples which showed the peaks near 400nm. The pH 9.0 was chosen due to the maximum blue shifted wavelength of 361nm, which was true for the previously studied solution. The UV–vis spectra were also recorded for the effect of time on the growth of nanostructures in solution, in the range of 3h to 1 month as elaborated in Fig. 1(b). The slow decrease of absorbance with time reveals that some particles are getting adsorbed due to interaction with the cell walls. However no change in wavelength with time shows that the particles are under the control of capping agent and hence highly stabilized in solution form. 3.2 Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy The FTIR spectroscopy was used to disclose the surface interaction of l-methionine to the Ni NWs and the results are displayed in Fig. 2 . The prominent and broad band of medium intensity in the range 3400–3000cm−1 in pure methionine is due to NH stretching [17], while some workers reported it at 3431cm−1 [18]. The shift of this band to higher frequency is due to Ni interaction with oxidized l-methionine. The variation in IR-spectral bands induced by l-methionine encapsulation over Ni NWs surface can be compared with ZnS:Mn nanocrystals capped with amino acids where strong peaks around 2950cm−1 and 1600cm−1 were assigned to Zn coordinated by amino group via NH2 [18]. In our case these bands are seen at 2920cm−1 and 1580cm−1 in l-methionine capped Ni NWs. This supports the surface binding of newly fabricated Ni NWs with l-methionine via NH2 and not via COO group. The evidence is further strengthened by the presence of clear and well resolved IR band at 2580cm−1 in l-methionine, that appeared at little longer wavelength of 2621cm−1 in β-dl-methionine [17]. This is attributed to the existence of intramolecular hydrogen bonding at carboxyl and amino groups as (N–H⋯O) (zwiterionic system). So this band was disappeared in the IR spectrum of Ni NWs due to surface binding of l-methionine via amino linkage, which also confirms the finishing of zwiterionic linkage. On the other hand many vibrational modes resulted from side chain of l-methionine remained unaltered, like bands around 1587cm−1 and 1415cm−1 showing the presence of –COO group [19]. In our case these bands appeared at 1580cm−1 and 1410cm−1 for l-methionine as well as Ni NWs. In addition there is no change in the signal at 1350cm−1 (specific for S–CH3) both in l-methionine and Ni NWs against the previous data where there was a shift in this signal from 1345cm−1 to 1311cm−1 in case formation of seleno methionine [20]. This confirms that there is no interaction of Ni with methionine via S–CH3. 3.3 Scanning electron microscopy This study was undertaken to investigate the changes related to size and morphology of newly synthesized l-methionine capped Ni NWs. The SEM images were recorded for different molar ratio of Ni/methionine to see the effect on morphology and size of Ni NWs. Fig. 3(a–c) represents the Ni/methionine molar ratio of 1:2, 1:4 and 1:6, respectively. The brighter areas observed in SEM images illustrate the presence of newly formed Ni NWs on surface of the glass cover slip. Small sized Ni NWs were resulted at higher molar ratio of Ni/l-methionine as evident from SEM images shown in Fig. 3(c). The NWs in each case are double strand extended in parallel with closed ends in most cases. Most of Ni NWs are branched as well. The most common and widely accepted factors for size control are concentration of the precursor salt and capping agent [21]. The relatively bigger Ni NWs formed with average length of 9.8μm and average size (width) of 70nm (single strand) were resulted from 1:2 ratio of the Ni/methionine as shown in Fig. 3(a) and low resolution SEM image of the same sample in Fig. S-2(a). This suggests that the Ni(II) ions when reduced to Ni0 particles are co-angulated by the nucleation process and form bigger aggregates (NWs). Fig. 3(b) and its low resolution image shown in Fig. S-2(b) confirms relatively smaller nanowires which elaborate the encapsulation of Ni0 particles with l-methionine molecules using 1:4 ratio of the Ni/l-methionine. The estimated average length and width in this case was 3.6μm and 85nm, respectively. The Ni NWs with average length x width of 6.8μm×55nm were resulted from 1:6 ratio of the Ni/l-methionine mixture as shown in Fig. 3(c) and a low resolution image of the same sample in Fig. S-2(c). This study reveals that the concentration of precursor salt and capping material are responsible for size and morphology of nanostructured materials [22]. Hence one can control the length and breadth of the Ni NWs by varying the molar ratio of Ni and l-methionine. 3.4 XRD study XRD study was undertaken to confirm the metallic and crystalline nature as well as size (width) of l-methionine Ni NWs. The results are shown in Fig. 4 with respective, 1:2, 1:4 and 1:6 ratio of Ni/l-methionine as that shown in Fig. 3. The data show that the pure Ni (fcc) patterns with (111) and (200) planes are true in case of samples having Ni/l-methionine ratio of 1:2 and 1:4 (Fig. 4(a and b)) while only (111) planes are observed for sample with Ni/l-methionine ratio of 1:6 (Fig. 4(c)). In Fig. 4(a and b) the possibility of formation Ni(OH)2 and NiO may not be ruled out [7,23]. However, in case of Fig. 4(c) (with 1:6 ratio of Ni/methionine) weak peaks of Ni(OH)2 or NiO are not seen. It means that the more methionine addition has prevented the Ni NWs from oxidation/hydroxylation. The results are in good agreement with those cited elsewhere [10,7]. The size determination using XRD was carried out by Scherrer formula [24]: L = K λ β cos ⁡ θ where K and λ have the value of 0.94 and 1.54184Å, β represents half width of peak and θ is half of the angle in degrees. The average size (width) of Ni NWs by mentioned equation were 64nm, 85nm and 51nm, respectively for sample having 1:2, 1:4 and 1:6 ratio of Ni/l-methionine. These sizes are quite closer to those obtained by SEM, which further confirms the validity of XRD method for size (width) determination. 3.5 Application of Ni NWs as catalyst The catalytic transfer hydrogenation reactions are highly important and advantageous for many reasons particularly for large-scale synthesis of many chemical compounds [22]. Such studies have been carried out for conversion of IPA to acetone in presence of oxidizing agents like di-oxygen which help to remove two hydrogen atoms, one from –OH group and other form secondary carbon atom (C–H) of the IPA molecules using Pt catalyst [25]. Other similar studies [11–13] are worth mentioning due to industrial as well as environmental point of view. We used rich hydrogen source NaBH4 with and without l-methionine capped Ni NWs to mediate the transfer of molecular hydrogen via the surface of highly active sites of newly synthesized Ni NWs. Fig. 5 describes various aspects of catalytic oxidative transfer hydrogenation of IPA to acetone in the presence/absence of Ni NWs and NaBH4 using UV–vis spectrometry as diagnostic tool. Fig. 5(a) tells about the effect of varying concentration of NaBH4 on the conversion of IPA to acetone in the absence of Ni NWs. The spectra show that no acetone is formed which gives absorption at around 265nm [16]. Fig. 5(b) shows the conversion of different amount of IPA (0.02–0.12M) to acetone via oxidative transfer hydrogenation in presence of fixed concentration of NaBH4 (0.005M) and Ni NWs (0.1mg). A plot of IPA concentration Vs absorbance is given in the inset of Fig. 5(b). Increase in absorbance of acetone formation (around 257nm in our case; may be due to different pH) with increase in IPA concentration under fixed amount of Ni NWs in the presence of 0.005M discloses the catalytic potential of Ni NWs. The use of small concentration of NaBH4 (0.005M) is however necessary as it provides BH4 − ions in the aqueous medium, which help Ni NWs to remove the hydrogen from OH group of IPA molecules to carry out the catalytic transfer hydrogenation reaction of IPA to acetone. Consequently the rate of transfer hydrogenation (oxidation in this case) of IPA to acetone is regarded independent of NaBH4 concentration. Progress of the product (acetone) formation for fixed amount of IPA was also monitored using different quantities of Ni NWs (0.1–0.5mg) immobilized on glass cover slip at fixed concentration (0.005M) of NaBH4. The results show increase in absorption of acetone with increase in the amount of Ni NWs as shown in Fig. 5(c). The inset shows the exponential trend for variation of the amount of Ni NWs verses absorbance (representing the extent of acetone formation). This demonstrates that increase in the amount of Ni NWs favors to enhance the rate of reaction exponentially by providing more surface area and hence availability of more active sites for oxidative catalytic transfer hydrogenation reaction (formation of acetone from IPA). The reaction was completed in 60s under UV–vis irradiations. Scheme 2 elaborates the over all reaction for catalytic transfer hydrogenation of IPA to acetone. The proposed step-wise mechanism for the above reaction is demonstrated below which is nearly similar to the reactions carried out in presence of supported Cu catalysts [26]. (1) (CH3)2CHOH+NiNWs→(CH3)2CHO–Ni NWs+H–NiNWs (2) (CH3)2CHOH–NiNWs+Ni NWs→(CH3)2CO–NiNWs+H–Ni (3) (CH3)2CO–NiNWs→(CH3)2CO+NiNWs (4) 2H–NiNWs→H2 +NiNWs The rate of conversion of 0.12M IPA to acetone was decreased to half (50%) when treated with 0.5mg of Ni NWs (results not shown) without using NaBH4. It means that the presence of NaBH4 as a hydrogen source is essential for efficient conversion of IPA to acetone. Fig. 5(d) represents the calibration curve and linear plot (inset) for varying amount of acetone in aqueous medium. This plot was used to investigate the amount of acetone formation in Fig. 5(b and c) by using the linear regression equation in the inset of Fig. 5(d). By comparing the results of in Fig. 5(c) with that in Fig. 5(d) it is evident that 0.12M of IPA is completely converted into 0.12M of acetone under the catalytic amount of 0.5mg of Ni NWs. In other words, IPA is converted to acetone with 100% yield. 3.6 Reuse/recycling of Ni NWs as catalyst Ni NWs (0.5mg) recovered and re-recovered by procedure described in experimental were reused 5 times for catalytic oxidative transfer hydrogenation of IPA (0.12M) (taking fresh solution each time) and the results are given in Table 1 . It is evident that the potential of the Ni NWs for catalytic conversion of IPA to acetone decreases. However the decrease in activity is still not very low. This behavior confirms that the reused catalyst is highly active despite some possible loss during each repeated washing. The slow deactivation of catalysts (Ni NWs) also confirms that the poisoning effect is negligible and one can use the catalyst for several transformations with appreciable yield. 4 Conclusions In view of our study it is concluded that the size of Ni NWS can be controlled by controlling parameters like, pH, concentration of precursor salt and capping agent. Furthermore, the increased concentration of methionine prevents the formation of Ni(OH)2 or NiO and results in mettalic Ni NWs. It is also emphasized that synthesized l-methionine capped Ni NWs are responsible for efficient transfer hydrogenation reaction regarding the conversion of IPA to 100% acetone. The re-use of catalyst with still higher yield of acetone further elaborates the importance of negligible poisoning of Ni NWs making it more economical. Hence we argue that the synthesized Ni NWs are green (recoverable and reusable) catalysts and are recommended for other transfer hydrogenation reactions of low molecular weight organic compounds under normal laboratory conditions. This new investigation is the simplistic, effortless and inexpensive approach for the fabrication of Ni nanostructures and their use in catalytic process. Acknowledgement Financial assistance by Higher Education Commission, Islamabad, Pakistan during this project is highly thanked and gratefully acknowledged. coredata.dc:description: Nickel nanowires (Ni NWs) were synthesized by the reducing action of hydrazine and stabilized by capping with l-methionine in aqueous solution. Characterization of the Ni NWs was carried out by UV–vis spectrometry, Fourier transform infra-red (FTIR) spectroscopy, Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) and X-ray diffractometry (XRD). Parameters like pH, concentration of reducing agent and molar ratio of Ni/l-methionine were found crucial for regulating the size of synthesized Ni NWs. The fabricated Ni NWs were employed as catalyst for catalytic oxidative dehydrogenation (transfer hydrogenation) of isopropanol (IPA) to acetone using aqueous medium in the presence of sodium borohydride (NaBH4) as hydrogen source. The effect of parameters studied during transfer hydrogenation of IPA included the concentration of IPA, concentration of NaBH4, time of reaction and amount of Ni NWs. The study revealed that IPA could be transformed into acetone with 100% yield in only 1min time of reaction. The catalyst was easy to recover and capable to be reused several times. The study shows that the catalytic transformation of IPA into acetone by synthesized Ni NWS in aqueous medium is environmental friendly in terms of recovery of catalyst, very fast and hence extremely economical.
coredata.dc:title: Synthesis of l-methionine stabilized nickel nanowires and their application for catalytic oxidative transfer hydrogenation of isopropanol
